channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: The Perl Conference in the Cloud
item.description: Instsead of the in-person Perl Conference, the TPF started to organize an even in the Cloud. You can already submit your talk proposals!

item.title: Perl Virtual Events?
item.description: As all the in-person events are cancelled many groups started to organize on-line events.

item.title: Code-Maven LinkedIn pages in English, Hebrew, and Spanish
item.description: I am experimenting with LinkedIn pages so I created 3. One for content in English, one for content in Hebrew, and one for content in Spanish. I would love if you followed at least one of them.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: PERL WEEKLY CHALLENGE: WEEK 56
item.description: You only expect top of the range solutions in Raku by Shahed.

item.title: PWC 056 â€º Path Sum
item.description: Ryan made good use generic Tree based solution. Highly Recommended.

item.title: PWC 056 â€º Diff-K
item.description: Ryan shared lots of Perl and Raku magic in one blog.

item.title: BLOG: The Weekly Challenge #056
item.description: List and Array dealt inside out this week.

item.title: Perl weekly challenge 56
item.description: Matthew blogged about his first contribution to the Perl Weekly Challenge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 56: Weaving and Flipping
item.description: I loved it. Great reading for someone learning Raku.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge # 56: Diff-k and Path Sum
item.description: Laurent's analytics discussion is unmatchable. Highly Recommended.

item.title: PERL WEEKLY CHALLENGE â€“ 056
item.description: Javier never scared of taking difficult path. He created package BTree::Node to solve the Path Sum task.

item.title: PWC 056: Task #1, Diff-K & Task #2, Path Sum
item.description: Jared shared his ideas behind his solutions to the weekly challenge.

item.title: Challenge 56 - Diff-K and Binary Trees
item.description: Dave came up with complete solution with package Node. Must Read.

item.title: Diff Sum by Raku
item.description: Do you want to learn something new about Raku? Please checkout the blog.

item.title: Graph Visualization (for small graphs)
item.description: Adam took us to the trip of Graph Visualization. Interesting Read.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 056
item.description: Recap of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 057
item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Grant Proposal: RakuAST
item.description: Grant proposal for RakuAST, an abstract syntax tree for the Raku language that will become part of the language specification.

item.title: Revisiting the Collatz Sequence (PWC 54)
item.description: Laurent revisited his work on Collatz Sequence and shared his findings.

item.title: Optimizing with Caching vs. Parallelizing (MCE::Map)
item.description: Nick Tonkin started very interesting discussion centered on the solution by Laurent Rosenfeld.

item.title: the Giant Planet of Perl
item.description: Cheok-Yin shared his discovery in the Giant Planet of Perl. Nice reading.

item.title: Perlmongers Conferences in the Time of Corona
item.description: Max shared the details of Virtual Conference he is setting up currently.

item.title: #456 - Conference in the Cloud
item.description:
Hi there

COVID-19 forced us to stay at home for sometime now. Do you miss attending conference? Luckily TPF is organising the Conference in the Cloud. It is going to be a 3-days event from 24-26 June 2020. If you would like to interact with the speakers and other attendees then you will need to pay registration fee $10. If you would like to be one of the speaker then you can submit your talk proposal by May 2 at 00:01 UTC. It is official called The Perl and Raku Conference in the Cloud (TPRCiC). Please check out the page for more information.

Have you tried Git Workflows? Curtis recently shared the git tools used by his company for software development. It is the best example of Git Workflows, in my humble opinion.

This is my 50th edition of Perl Weekly newsletter. Next month, I will complete 2 years of association with Perl Weekly. Thank you Gabor Szabo for giving me the opportunity.

Last but not the least, stay safe and stay indoor, if possible. Enjoy reading this week newsletter.
